keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, 38, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, with the first conviction occurring in August 2025 and a second scheduled for November 2025.
Rossi is described as a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk,' with authorities identifying him through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, with police and former family members challenging the authenticity of the death claim.
He fled to Scotland, where he was arrested while receiving treatment for COVID-19 due to distinctive tattoos linked to an Interpol notice.
He used multiple aliases over the years, including Arthur Knight, to evade capture and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
Rossi’s first trial ended in a guilty verdict in August 2025, and he received a sentence of five years to life in prison under Utah law for first-degree rape.
The victim in the first case testified about being groomed through a Craigslist ad, facing financial exploitation, and being raped in his apartment, with trauma continuing years later.
He is also facing fraud charges in Ohio, where he was previously convicted of sex-related offenses in 2008.
He did not testify during trial, and during sentencing maintained innocence, saying 'I am not guilty of this. These women are lying.'
The case highlights the risks of rape kit backlogs and the importance of DNA databases in identifying perpetrators who flee the country or fake their death.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog, Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 and fled the U.S., using aliases like Arthur Knight and hiding in Scotland where he was arrested due to distinctive tattoos linked to an Interpol notice. He was extradited to Utah in January 2024 and sentenced by District Judge Barry Lawrence to a prison term of five years to life, reflecting the severity of his actions as a serial abuser and flight risk. The case underscores the importance of DNA database utilization in solving cold cases and the dangers posed by individuals who evade justice through deception, including false death claims and identity fraud. The victim described the trauma of grooming, financial exploitation, and assault, emphasizing the need for accountability and safety in the face of sexual violence.
title: Man Accused of Faking His Own Death and Fleeding the US After Rape Charges Gets at Least Five Years in Prison
